thread.title: Indy moms want to light a fire under city to do good
thread.title_full: Indy moms want to light a fire under city to do good

author: maureen.gilmer@indystar.com
title: Indy moms want to light a fire under city to do good
text:
Indy moms want to light a fire under city to do good Maureen C. Gilmer , maureen.gilmer@indystar.com Published 9:27 p.m. ET Feb. 17, 2017 | Updated 13 minutes ago CLOSE x Share Do Good Indy started with moms who wanted to give back to their communities and involve their kids too. (February 2017) Kelly Wilkinson/IndyStar 'Sometimes it takes an extreme shift in what we know as normal to light a fire under us.' Buy Photo Christie Koester, right, holding her son Max, talks about some of the donations, right, given to Do Good Indy, during the group's play date, Wednesday, February 16, 2017. The group gathers donations, does supply drives and volunteer opportunities as a way to give back to the community. The founders of the Do Good Indy group are all mothers with young children. (Photo: Kelly Wilkinson/IndyStar) Buy Photo 293 CONNECT COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
A big idea was born in the tiny living room of a South Broad Ripple bungalow recently. While toddlers played and babies slept nearby, their moms sat on the floor and plotted how they might mobilize into a force for good in the community. It was an activist play date, they called it. 
It was the beginning of Do Good Indy , a Facebook group organized last fall to spread goodwill and good vibes throughout the city, lifting up marginalized populations along the way. 
They women even developed a vision statement: "Through coordinated giving drives and opportunities for deeper connections, Do Good Indy will provide a direct positive impact by championing both the need for support and acceptance of vulnerable populations as a critical component in a civilized society." 
Christie Koester, a mother of two toddlers who works from home, is one of five Indianapolis moms leading the charge for kindness as a way to fight fear in parts of this city and others around the country. 
It started in response to the rancor of the last presidential election, but it's not about politics, she insists; it's about people. "We are strictly nonpartisan. We accept anyone who wants to do good in Indy." 
To that end, Do Good Indy has been busy the past few months, collecting and donating carload after carload of clothing, toiletries and books to local organizations serving vulnerable populations, including the Immigrant Welcome Center , Exodus Refugee , the Julian Center , which supports abused women, and Damien Center , which helps people with HIV/AIDS. 
"There are so many amazing organizations doing amazing work in Indy," Koester said. By hosting supply drives for some of them, Do Good Indy also aims to connect people to these organizations, whether to volunteer or write a check. 
"Glorified middle women" is how she describes the group, working to make it easy for people to clean out their closets or garages and donate to an organization maybe they haven't heard of before. Buy Photo 
Christie Koester, from left, Emily Miller, holding her son Emerson Miller, Stephanie Sasena, Jazzy O'Brien, and Katie Swaney pose with some donations, during a Do Good Indy play date, Wednesday, February 16, 2017. The group gathers donations and distributes them to nonprofits around the city. Greyson Sasena and Ethan McArdle stand by their moms, right. (Photo: Kelly Wilkinson/IndyStar) 
For Kwesie Brown, program director at the Immigrant Welcome Center, 910 Shelby St., the do-gooders came along at the right time. The Southside center was seeing more people coming in needing referrals for basic supplies. 
"We needed more help, more hands," he said. "They are doing a very great thing for us and for immigrants and refugees." 
Last month, the group collected coats and toys and set up a giveaway at the center, attracting more than 40 families. 
According to the U.S. Census Bureau, 8.3 percent of Indianapolis residents are foreign-born, and in 11.8 percent of homes, a language other than English is spoken. 
The Indianapolis metro population grew by 15.2 percent in the past decade due in large part to an influx of foreign-born residents. 
Nearly half of the newcomers to Indianapolis come from Latin American countries. The top five countries of origin for immigrants to Indiana as of 2012 were Burma, Mexico, India, China and the Philippines. Mom came from Cuba 
Emily Miller is the daughter of a first-generation immigrant from Cuba. Her mom came to the U.S. with her parents as a toddler in 1960. After weeks in a refugee camp in Miami, the family of five was resettled in Chicago with help from organizations that provided furniture, clothing and toiletries, the same things Miller and the Do Good Indy group provide for people in need here. 
"My mom still keeps in touch with the family that helped them when they moved to Chicago," Miller said. "Growing up with that background, being able to continue that cycle of helping people resettle means a lot to me." 
On Wednesday morning, the five Do Good Indy founders, a few of their friends and about a dozen babies and toddlers crowded into Katie Swaney's home, where a stack of donations was waiting to be sorted.
